newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian shares ease, traders differ on down trend.
newsitem.headline: Russian shares ease, traders differ on down trend.

text.p: Leading Russian shares eased at the opening on Tuesday and traders said the short-term future of the market depended on domestic support as Westerners, worried U.S. interest rates could rise further, refused to buy.
The Russian Trading System 23-share index opened slightly down at 301.23 on Tuesday after 301.30 previously.

"We're expecting a further drop in blue chips. Western operators have joined us again (after the Easter holidays) and their worries about a further rise in interest rates are being reflected in the market," said Alexander Gritskevich, head of trading operations at Trinfiko.
Despite recent heavy falls on Wall Street, Russian securities have rallied over the last few days, mainly on domestic support, traders say.

But at 1315 GMT regional utility Irkutskenergo IRGZ.RTS had fallen to $0.253 from Monday's $0.257 close. National power company UES EESR.RTS was off at $0.1900 after $0.1917 on Monday. Both had recovered slightly from opening lows.
Some dealers saw the market hovering at current levels on continuing domestic support.
"The world climate is not good right now but the Russian market has held up surprisingly well," said ING Baring's chief equity trader Peter Kizenko.
"The market will not rally strongly but will be around the same levels, maybe a bit down in sympathy with the rest of the world."
But other traders said leading Russian shares would ease further in the next few days.

"I think prices will fall back to the levels they were at before the recent rise, Russian investors can't keep up the pressure," Gritskevich said, adding that there were no aggressive domestic purchases to offset profit-taking.
